flags.evidence:
The script claims to fetch/prepare state minimum wage controls, but it only creates a FIPS-to-abbreviation lookup (no minimum wage levels by state-year) and then defers construction to later steps. In the provided pipeline code, no later script actually constructs or merges minimum wage series, so the provenance and existence of the stated state-level control are unclear.: state_min_wage <- tibble(
  statefip = 1:56,
  state_abbr = c("AL", "AK", "AZ", "AR", "CA", "CO", "CT", "DE", "DC", "FL",
                 "GA", "HI", "ID", "IL", "IN", "IA", "KS", "KY", "LA", "ME",
                 "MD", "MA", "MI", "MN", "MS", "MO", "MT", "NE", "NV", "NH",
                 "NJ", "NM", "NY", "NC", "ND", "OH", "OK", "OR", "PA", "RI",
                 "SC", "SD", "TN", "TX", "UT", "VT", "VA", "WA", "WV", "WI",
                 "WY", NA, NA, NA, NA, NA)
) %>%
  filter(!is.na(state_abbr))

# For now, we'll construct minimum wage data in the cleaning script
# using known values for the analysis period

Manuscript states minimum wage controls are incorporated, but in the provided code (01_fetch_data.R, 02_clean_data.R, 04_main_analysis.R, 07_tables.R) there is no construction of a state-year minimum wage variable and no regression specification includes it. This is a substantive mismatch because it affects claims about addressing concurrent policies.: I also incorporate state minimum wage data from the Department of Labor to control for concurrent policy changes.

The code’s IPUMS extract (01_fetch_data.R) does not request CPS/IPUMS imputation flag variables for earnings (e.g., an allocation/imputation indicator). Correspondingly, 02_clean_data.R never filters out imputed wage observations. If the paper’s claim is intended literally (dropping imputed wages), it is not implemented in the provided code.: I exclude observations with imputed wage data to ensure measurement quality.

The script explicitly extracts the Callaway–Sant’Anna overall ATT (cs_att/cs_se) but does not use it in the exported main-results table (etable only includes m1, m3, m4, m5). This creates a risk that the headline estimator described in the manuscript (C-S) is not actually what appears in the main LaTeX table, or that only the more favorable/specification-aligned results are shown. At minimum, there is an internal inconsistency between the code comments and the produced table output.: # (2) C-S Simple ATT
# Extract from results
cs_att <- results$att_simple$overall.att
cs_se <- results$att_simple$overall.se

# Export table
etable(m1, m3, m4, m5,
       tex = TRUE,
       ...
       file = "tables/table2_main_results.tex")

Random treatment assignment and seed-setting appear, but they are used for randomization inference/permutation tests (a robustness/inference procedure explicitly described in the manuscript). This is not evidence of fabricated outcome data; it is acceptable if clearly labeled as inference/robustness, which it is.: set.seed(20260203)  # Reproducible
n_permutations <- 500  # Reduced for computational tractability
...
fake_treated_states <- sample(all_states, n_treated)
...
fake_years <- sample(actual_treated$first_treat, n_treated, replace = FALSE)

Outcome-based trimming is performed (dropping observations outside 1st–99th percentile of hourly wages). However, bounds are computed using only pre-treatment years and then applied to all years, which is a principled approach the manuscript explicitly defends. This is not a red flag by itself, but it is still an outcome-based sample restriction that should be transparently reported (it is, in the manuscript).: pre_treatment_wages <- df %>%
  filter(income_year <= 2020) %>%
  pull(hourly_wage)

wage_bounds <- quantile(pre_treatment_wages, c(0.01, 0.99), na.rm = TRUE)
...
df <- df %>%
  filter(hourly_wage >= wage_bounds[1], hourly_wage <= wage_bounds[2])

summary.executive_summary: The manuscript claims the regressions include controls for state-year minimum wages, but the provided workflow (01_fetch_data.R, 02_clean_data.R, 04_main_analysis.R, 07_tables.R) never constructs, merges, or references any state-by-year minimum-wage variable. As a result, the main estimates and tables cannot reflect the stated minimum-wage controls, creating a direct mismatch between the described methodology and what the code actually implements.

top_issues.short: Manuscript states minimum wage controls are incorporated,...
